title: 103_s1452
content:
The Flood-Affected States Assistance Act of 1993 may be cited as the "Flood-Affected States Assistance Act". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Flood-Affected States Assistance Act of 1993, also known as the "Flood-Affected States Assistance Act," defines terms such as "designated" and "Secretary" for the purposes of the Act. "Designated" refers to states or political subdivisions declared by the President to have a major disaster or emergency due to the 1993 Midwest flooding, while "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "State agency" is defined in the Flood-Affected States Assistance Act of 1993 as the agency responsible for administering or supervising the State's plan approved under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The State agency administers or supervises the State's plan approved under specific sections of the Social Security Act. SEC. 3. Enhanced federal medical assistance percentage for services provided to certain individuals: During a 2-year period starting July 1, 1993, the federal medical assistance percentage for a State providing medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act to designated individuals will be 83 percent.

SEC. 4. Disregard of certain donated items and temporary financial assistance when determining eligibility for benefits under the AFDC and Medicaid programs. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, donations or financial assistance provided for disaster relief in the Midwest in 1993 will not be counted as income or resources for determining eligibility for benefits under certain social security programs. SEC. 5. INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY GRANT PROGRAM. Federal payment for designated individuals or families will be 100 percent of actual costs for a 2-year period starting April 1, 1993. The administrative cost limit is waived during this period. SEC. 6. Submission deadline extension for certain AFDC and jobs program reports. SEC. 6. Extension of submission deadline for certain AFDC and jobs program reports. Reports for designated State plans under parts A and F of the Social Security Act due by September 30, 1993, are now extended to December 31, 1993. SEC. 7. Temporary suspension of certain state quality control functions. During a specified period from September 1, 1993, to February 28, 1994, designated States are exempt from quality control requirements and have error rates deemed as zero for medical assistance payments under the Social Security Act. SEC. 8. A designated State is deemed compliant with child support data processing requirements until December 1, 1993. SEC. 9. Enhanced federal match for new eligibles. During a 2-year period starting on July 1, 1993, the Federal government will cover 100% of expenses for newly eligible individuals in State programs approved under specific sections of the Social Security Act. Newly eligible individuals are those who became eligible after July 1, 1993, exceeding the existing number of individuals. The Federal government will cover 100% of expenses for newly eligible individuals in State programs approved under specific sections of the Social Security Act for a 2-year period starting on July 1, 1993, exceeding the existing number of individuals. During a 2-year period starting on July 1, 1993, the Federal government will cover 100% of expenses for transitional housing special needs and jobs programs under specific sections of the Social Security Act. During a 2-year period starting on July 1, 1993, the Federal government will cover 100% of expenses for emergency assistance to families with children and certain optional medical services. SEC. 13 provides a 100% federal match for optional medical services in designated States for a 2-year period starting July 1, 1993. SEC. 14 offers a permanent enhanced federal match for states frequently declared disaster areas under the Individual and Family Grant Programs. Section 411(b) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to provide a 100 percent federal share of a grant to an individual or family if a major disaster has been declared in more than one-third of the counties in a State in 2 of the previous 5 calendar years.
